BiologicalClassification.chapterOverview: Chapter 1 of Biology class 11 introduces the concept of biological classification and taxonomy. It explores the organization and classification of living organisms based on their characteristics, evolutionary relationships, and shared features.

content.example: The process of categorizing and organizing living organisms based on their characteristics and evolutionary relationships.
The science of classification, identification, and naming of living organisms.
The naming system in which each species is assigned a unique two-part scientific name, consisting of its genus and species.
The highest taxonomic rank in the classification of organisms, representing the broadest category.
The classification system that categorizes organisms into five kingdoms: Monera, Protista, Fungi, Plantae, and Animalia.
Distinctive features and traits exhibited by organisms in each of the five kingdoms.
A system of organizing living organisms into a hierarchical structure, including domains, kingdoms, phyla, classes, orders, families, genera, and species.
The various levels of hierarchy in the taxonomic classification, each representing a different degree of relatedness.
Memory aids or techniques used to remember the sequence and order of classification categories.

PlantKingdom.chapterOverview: Chapter 2 of Biology class 11 focuses on the study of the plant kingdom. It explores the classification, characteristics, and diversity of plants, including their evolutionary history, life cycles, and adaptations to different environments.

content.example: The group of multicellular, eukaryotic organisms that possess cell walls and carry out photosynthesis to produce their own food.
The origin and diversification of plant life on Earth, from ancient algae to modern-day land plants.
The systematic arrangement of plants into different groups based on their characteristics, such as the presence or absence of specialized tissues, vascular systems, and reproductive structures.
A group of plants that lack true roots, stems, and leaves, and their bodies are not differentiated into distinct organs.
Simple, photosynthetic organisms that are primarily aquatic and range from unicellular to multicellular forms.
Non-vascular plants that lack specialized tissues for conducting water and nutrients, including mosses, liverworts, and hornworts.
Vascular plants that reproduce by spores and have specialized tissues for conducting water and nutrients, including ferns and fern allies.
A group of pteridophytes characterized by large, compound leaves called fronds and a distinct lifecycle involving spores.
Pteridophytes that share some characteristics with ferns but are not classified as true ferns, including club mosses, horsetails, and whisk ferns.
Seed-bearing plants that produce naked seeds (not enclosed in fruits) and typically have cones as reproductive structures, including conifers, cycads, ginkgoes, and gnetophytes.
A group of gymnosperms that typically have needle-like or scale-like leaves and bear cones, including pine, spruce, fir, and cedar trees.
Palm-like gymnosperms that have large compound leaves and typically grow in tropical and subtropical regions.
Flowering plants that produce seeds enclosed in fruits. They are the most diverse and widespread group of plants, including herbs, shrubs, and trees.
A class of angiosperms characterized by having a single cotyledon (seed leaf), parallel-veined leaves, and flower parts in multiples of three.
A class of angiosperms characterized by having two cotyledons (seed leaves), net-veined leaves, and flower parts in multiples of four or five.

MorphologyFloweringPlants.chapterOverview: Chapter 3 of Biology class 11 focuses on the study of the morphology (external structure) of flowering plants. It explores the various parts of a plant, their functions, adaptations, and their role in plant growth, reproduction, and survival.

content.example: The underground part of a plant that anchors it in the soil, absorbs water and minerals, and stores food.
Different forms of roots, such as taproots, fibrous roots, adventitious roots, and modified roots like aerial roots, prop roots, and storage roots.
Specialized adaptations of roots for specific functions, such as support, respiration, and nutrient storage.
The above-ground part of a plant that provides support, transports water, minerals, and nutrients, and serves as the site for photosynthesis.
Different forms of stems, such as herbaceous stems, woody stems, underground stems, and modified stems like tendrils, thorns, and tubers.
Specialized adaptations of stems for specific functions, such as climbing, protection, and storage of water and food.
The main site of photosynthesis in a plant, responsible for capturing sunlight and converting it into chemical energy.
The arrangement, shape, venation (vein pattern), and structure of leaves.

Specialized leaf structures and adaptations for specific functions, such as water conservation (xerophytic leaves), insect trapping (insectivorous leaves), and storage of water and food (succulent leaves).
The arrangement and grouping of flowers on a plant.
Different patterns and types of inflorescence, including racemose (indeterminate) and cymose (determinate) inflorescence.
The different parts of a flower, such as sepals, petals, stamens, and carpels, and their functions in sexual reproduction.
The mature ovary of a flower, containing seeds and often serving as a means of seed dispersal.
Different forms and types of fruits, including fleshy fruits, dry fruits, simple fruits, aggregate fruits, and multiple fruits.
The structure and parts of a seed, such as the seed coat, embryo, and endosperm, and their roles in seed germination and plant propagation.

AnatomyFloweringPlants.chapterOverview: Chapter 4 of Biology class 11 focuses on the study of the internal structure and anatomy of flowering plants. It explores the different tissues, cells, and organs that make up plants, their functions, and their role in plant growth, development, and physiological processes.

content.example: Groups or collections of specialized cells that perform specific functions in a plant.
Undifferentiated, actively dividing cells responsible for plant growth and development.
Mature, differentiated plant cells that perform specialized functions, including simple tissues (parenchyma, collenchyma, and sclerenchyma) and complex tissues (xylem and phloem).
The internal structure and organization of stem tissues, including the arrangement of vascular bundles, pith, cortex, and secondary growth (in woody stems).
The increase in length of a plant stem due to cell division and elongation in the apical meristem.
The increase in girth or thickness of a plant stem due to cell division and differentiation in the lateral meristem (vascular cambium and cork cambium).
The internal structure and organization of leaf tissues, including the epidermis, mesophyll (palisade and spongy parenchyma), stomata, and vascular bundles.
Specialized adaptations of leaves for specific functions, such as tendrils, spines, and insect-trapping leaves.
The internal structure and organization of root tissues, including the epidermis, cortex, endodermis, pericycle, vascular tissues (xylem and phloem), and root hairs.
Specialized adaptations of roots for specific functions, such as storage roots, prop roots, and pneumatophores.
The internal structure and organization of flower tissues, including the different whorls (sepals, petals, stamens, and carpels) and their arrangement.
The male reproductive structure of flowering plants, consisting of the male gametophyte enclosed within a protective outer wall.
The female reproductive structure of flowering plants, consisting of the female gametophyte enclosed within the ovule.

CellUnitLife.chapterOverview: Chapter 5 of Biology class 11 focuses on the study of cells, which are the fundamental units of life. It explores the structure and functions of cells, their organization into tissues and organs, and their significance in understanding life processes.

content.example: The basic structural and functional unit of all living organisms.
The scientific theory that states that all living organisms are composed of cells, cells are the basic units of structure and function in organisms, and all cells arise from pre-existing cells.
Different types of cells, such as prokaryotic cells (bacteria) and eukaryotic cells (plants, animals, fungi, and protists).
The semipermeable outer boundary of a cell that regulates the passage of substances in and out of the cell.
The jelly-like fluid that fills the cell, contains various organelles, and serves as the site for cellular processes.
The control center of the cell that contains the genetic material (DNA) and regulates cellular activities.
Specialized structures within cells that perform specific functions, such as mitochondria, endoplasmic reticulum, Golgi apparatus, lysosomes, and chloroplasts.
The series of events that take place in a cell leading to its division and duplication of DNA.
The process of cell division that results in the formation of two genetically identical daughter cells.
The process of cell division that occurs in reproductive cells (gametes) and results in the formation of four genetically different daughter cells.
The importance of cell division in growth, development, tissue repair, and reproduction.
The process by which cells break down organic molecules (such as glucose) to release energy in the form of ATP (adenosine triphosphate).
The first step of cellular respiration, occurring in the cytoplasm, where glucose is partially broken down into pyruvate.
The second step of cellular respiration, occurring in the mitochondria, where pyruvate is further broken down to produce energy-rich molecules.
The final step of cellular respiration, occurring in the mitochondria, where energy from the breakdown of glucose is used to generate ATP.
The process by which green plants and some other organisms convert light energy into chemical energy (glucose) using carbon dioxide and water.
The organelles in plant cells where photosynthesis takes place, containing chlorophyll and other pigments.
The initial stage of photosynthesis, occurring in the thylakoid membranes of chloroplasts, where light energy is used to generate ATP and NADPH.
The second stage of photosynthesis, occurring in the stroma of chloroplasts, where ATP and NADPH are used to convert carbon dioxide into glucose.

CellCycleDivision.chapterOverview: Chapter 6 of Biology class 11 focuses on the study of the cell cycle, which is the series of events that take place in a cell leading to its division. It explores the different phases of the cell cycle, the process of mitosis and meiosis, and their significance in growth, development, and reproduction.

content.example: The series of events that take place in a cell leading to its division and duplication of DNA.
The longest phase of the cell cycle, consisting of G1 (growth phase 1), S (DNA synthesis), and G2 (growth phase 2).
The phase of the cell cycle where cell division occurs, including mitosis (in somatic cells) and meiosis (in reproductive cells).
The process of cell division that results in the formation of two genetically identical daughter cells.
The different stages of mitosis, including prophase, metaphase, anaphase, and telophase.
The division of the cytoplasm that follows mitosis, resulting in the formation of two separate daughter cells.
The process of cell division that occurs in reproductive cells (gametes) and results in the formation of four genetically different daughter cells.
The two rounds of cell division in meiosis, including meiosis I and meiosis II, each consisting of prophase, metaphase, anaphase, and telophase.
The exchange of genetic material between homologous chromosomes during meiosis, resulting in genetic variation.
The importance of meiosis in sexual reproduction and the production of genetically diverse offspring.
Critical points in the cell cycle where regulatory proteins monitor and ensure the accuracy and integrity of cell division.
Proteins that control the progression of the cell cycle by activating or inactivating specific target proteins.
Programmed cell death that plays a crucial role in development, tissue homeostasis, and the elimination of damaged or abnormal cells.
A group of diseases characterized by uncontrolled cell division and the ability of cells to invade other tissues.
An abnormal mass or swelling of cells resulting from uncontrolled cell division.
The spread of cancer cells from the original site to other parts of the body through the bloodstream or lymphatic system.

content.definition: Role of Cell Cycle Regulation in Cancer
content.example: Malfunctioning cell cycle regulation mechanisms can contribute to the development and progression of cancer.

TransportPlants.chapterOverview: Chapter 7 of Biology class 11 focuses on the study of the transport system in plants. It explores the mechanisms by which plants transport water, minerals, and organic substances within their body, including the process of transpiration, absorption, and the role of specialized tissues like xylem and phloem.

content.example: Specialized tissues in plants responsible for the transport of water, minerals, and organic substances.
The vascular tissue in plants that transports water and minerals from roots to the aerial parts of the plant.
The vascular tissue in plants that transports organic substances (such as sugars) from the leaves to other parts of the plant.
Tiny extensions of root epidermal cells that increase the surface area for water and mineral absorption.
The osmotic pressure generated in the roots that helps in the upward movement of water and minerals.
The phenomenon of water rising in narrow tubes against the force of gravity due to adhesive and cohesive forces.
The loss of water vapor from the aerial parts of the plant, mainly through the stomata in the leaves.
Tiny openings on the leaf surface that regulate the exchange of gases and the loss of water vapor.
Environmental factors like temperature, humidity, wind, and light intensity that influence the rate of transpiration.
The force exerted by transpiration that helps in the upward movement of water in plants.
The theory that explains the ascent of sap in plants, stating that water molecules are pulled upwards through xylem vessels due to the cohesive and adhesive forces.
The theory that suggests that root pressure generated in the roots pushes water up the xylem vessels.
The movement of organic substances (such as sugars) through the phloem from source to sink.
Inorganic nutrients required by plants for their growth and development, including macronutrients (such as nitrogen, phosphorus, and potassium) and micronutrients (such as iron, zinc, and manganese).
Minerals play vital roles in plant processes, including enzyme activation, osmotic balance, and structural integrity.
Signs of nutrient deficiencies in plants, such as yellowing of leaves (chlorosis) or stunted growth.

MineralNutrition.chapterOverview: Chapter 8 of Biology class 11 focuses on the study of mineral nutrition in plants. It explores the essential mineral elements required by plants for their growth and development, their functions, and the processes of absorption, transport, and deficiency symptoms.

content.example: Mineral elements required by plants in relatively large quantities, including nitrogen, phosphorus, potassium, calcium, magnesium, and sulfur.
Mineral elements required by plants in small quantities, including iron, manganese, zinc, copper, molybdenum, boron, and chlorine.
Essential for the synthesis of proteins, nucleic acids, and chlorophyll.
Involved in energy transfer and storage, cell division, and nucleic acid synthesis.
Plays a role in osmoregulation, enzyme activation, and stomatal regulation.
Required for cell wall development, membrane stability, and signal transduction.
Essential for chlorophyll synthesis, enzyme activation, and photosynthesis.
Involved in protein synthesis, enzyme activation, and the formation of certain vitamins.
Required for chlorophyll synthesis and electron transport in photosynthesis.
Plays a role in photosynthesis, enzyme activation, and nitrogen metabolism.
Essential for enzyme activation, protein synthesis, and growth regulation.
Involved in electron transport, enzyme activation, and lignin synthesis.
Required for nitrogen metabolism and enzyme activation.
Plays a role in cell wall synthesis, pollen development, and carbohydrate metabolism.
Involved in photosynthesis, osmoregulation, and ion balance.
Tiny extensions of root epidermal cells that increase the surface area for mineral ion absorption.
The energy-dependent process by which plants absorb mineral ions against their concentration gradient.
The movement of mineral ions through the cytoplasm of cells via plasmodesmata.
The movement of mineral ions through the cell walls and intercellular spaces.
The innermost layer of the root cortex that regulates the entry of mineral ions into the xylem.
Stunted growth, yellowing of leaves (chlorosis), and reduced protein synthesis.
Stunted growth, purple discoloration of leaves, and poor root development.
Yellowing and curling of leaf margins, poor flowering, and reduced fruit quality.
Poor root development, stunted growth, and blossom-end rot in fruits.
Yellowing between veins of older leaves, reduced chlorophyll production.
Yellowing of leaves, stunted growth, and reduced protein synthesis.
Yellowing of young leaves (chlorosis) with green veins.
Interveinal chlorosis, reduced growth, and poor fruit formation.
Stunted growth, interveinal chlorosis, and malformed leaves.
Dieback of shoots, wilting, and browning of leaf tips.
Yellowing of leaves, stunted growth, and reduced nitrogen fixation.
Brittle leaves, poor root development, and distorted flowers.
Wilting, bronzing of leaves, and reduced growth.

PhotosynthesisPlants.chapterOverview: Chapter 9 of Biology class 11 focuses on the process of photosynthesis in higher plants. It explores the structure and function of chloroplasts, the light-dependent and light-independent reactions of photosynthesis, factors affecting photosynthesis, and the significance of photosynthesis in the ecosystem.

content.example: An organelle found in plant cells that is the site of photosynthesis.
Membrane-bound compartments inside chloroplasts where the light-dependent reactions of photosynthesis occur.
Stacks of thylakoids in chloroplasts.
The fluid-filled space surrounding the thylakoids in chloroplasts where the light-independent reactions of photosynthesis occur.
The process by which pigments in chloroplasts capture light energy.
Protein complexes in thylakoid membranes that contain pigments and other molecules involved in capturing and converting light energy.
A series of electron carrier molecules in thylakoid membranes that transfer electrons and generate ATP and NADPH.
The movement of protons (H+) across thylakoid membranes through ATP synthase, which generates ATP.
The splitting of water molecules into oxygen, protons (H+), and electrons in the thylakoid lumen.
The incorporation of atmospheric carbon dioxide (CO2) into organic compounds during photosynthesis.
The enzyme responsible for catalyzing the first step of carbon fixation in the Calvin cycle.
The conversion of carbon dioxide (CO2) into sugars (such as glucose) using ATP and NADPH generated during the light-dependent reactions.
The regeneration of the molecule Ribulose-1,5-bisphosphate (RuBP), which is required for the continuation of the Calvin cycle.
The amount of light energy available for photosynthesis.
The level of carbon dioxide in the surrounding environment.
The ambient temperature, which affects the activity of enzymes involved in photosynthesis.
The availability of water for plant cells to maintain turgor pressure and facilitate the transport of materials.

topics.title: Significance of Photosynthesis in the Ecosystem

content.example: Photosynthesis is the primary source of atmospheric oxygen.
Photosynthesis removes carbon dioxide from the atmosphere and converts it into organic compounds.
Photosynthesis provides energy for all other organisms in the ecosystem through the production of glucose and other organic molecules.
Photosynthesis is the foundation of food production in plants, supporting the growth of crops and sustaining ecosystems.

RespirationPlants.chapterOverview: Chapter 10 of Biology class 11 focuses on the process of respiration in plants. It explores the different pathways of respiration, including aerobic and anaerobic respiration, the role of mitochondria in respiration, and the significance of respiration in plant growth and survival.

content.example: The first step of aerobic respiration, which occurs in the cytoplasm and involves the breakdown of glucose into pyruvate.
The second step of aerobic respiration, which occurs in the mitochondria and involves the oxidation of pyruvate and the production of ATP and reduced coenzymes.
The final step of aerobic respiration, which occurs in the mitochondria and involves the transfer of electrons and the generation of ATP through oxidative phosphorylation.
The process of generating ATP through the electron transport chain and oxidative phosphorylation.
The process of deriving energy from organic molecules in the absence of oxygen.
A type of anaerobic respiration in which pyruvate is converted into ethanol and carbon dioxide.
A type of anaerobic respiration in which pyruvate is converted into lactic acid.
The amount of ATP produced through anaerobic respiration is much less compared to aerobic respiration.
An organelle found in eukaryotic cells that is the site of aerobic respiration.
The innermost compartment of the mitochondrion where the Krebs cycle takes place.
The folded inner membrane of the mitochondrion where the electron transport chain is located.
An enzyme located in the mitochondrial inner membrane that synthesizes ATP during oxidative phosphorylation.

topics.title: Significance of Respiration in Plant Growth and Survival

content.example: Respiration provides ATP, the energy currency of cells, for various metabolic processes in plants.
Energy derived from respiration is crucial for plant growth, cell division, and the synthesis of new molecules.
Respiration supports the active transport of nutrients from the soil into plant roots.
Respiration helps plants cope with environmental stressors, such as drought or temperature fluctuations.
Respiration is essential for seed germination, providing energy for the growth of the embryonic plant.
